prBranchIssues.title: Lack of error handling for unexpected response formats.
prBranchIssues.description: Lack of error handling for unexpected response formats.
prBranchIssues.codeSnippet: Returns a `Response` object with `Body` methods added for convenience. So you can, for example, call `ky.get(input).json()` directly without having to await the `Response` first. When called like that, an appropriate `Accept` header will be set depending on the body method used. Unlike the `Body` methods of `window.Fetch`; these will throw an `HTTPError` if the response status is not in the range of `200...299`. Also, `.json()` will return an empty string if body is empty or the response status is `204` instead of throwing a parse error due to an empty body.
codeContext: Returns a `Response` object with `Body` methods added for convenience. So you can, for example, call `ky.get(input).json()` directly without having to await the `Response` first. When called like that, an appropriate `Accept` header will be set depending on the body method used. Unlike the `Body` methods of `window.Fetch`; these will throw an `HTTPError` if the response status is not in the range of `200...299`. Also, `.json()` will return an empty string if body is empty or the response status is `204` instead of throwing a parse error due to an empty body.

issue.codeSnippet: Returns a `Response` object with `Body` methods added for convenience. So you can, for example, call `ky.get(input).json()` directly without having to await the `Response` first. When called like that, an appropriate `Accept` header will be set depending on the body method used. Unlike the `Body` methods of `window.Fetch`; these will throw an `HTTPError` if the response status is not in the range of `200...299`. Also, `.json()` will return an empty string if body is empty or the response status is `204` instead of throwing a parse error due to an empty body.
codeContext: Returns a `Response` object with `Body` methods added for convenience. So you can, for example, call `ky.get(input).json()` directly without having to await the `Response` first. When called like that, an appropriate `Accept` header will be set depending on the body method used. Unlike the `Body` methods of `window.Fetch`; these will throw an `HTTPError` if the response status is not in the range of `200...299`. Also, `.json()` will return an empty string if body is empty or the response status is `204` instead of throwing a parse error due to an empty body.
